Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Querying Massive Dynamic Biological Network Databases
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the functions served by different biological entities, such as genes, proteins and metabolites, through interactions in biological networks has been a prime goal in biological studies. One promising way to reach this goal is to perform comparative analysis among biological networks. Recently, there has been significant work in collecting and constructing biological networks. As a result, enormous amount of network data is already available. Biological databases today are very large in size and dynamic in nature. This project aims to develop scalable algorithms and tools that enable comparative analysis of very large and dynamic biological network databases. More specifically, it addresses the following problems. i) Develop scalable and accurate algorithms that allow comparing pairs of biological networks quickly while ensuring mathematically provable confidence bounds on the optimality of the results. ii) Develop efficient mining methods tailored to find small sets of representative subnetworks in massive sets of alternative biological network topologies. iii) Develop dynamic indexing methods for searching subnetworks in large collections of biological databases that can adapt to changes in the database (i.e., insertion of new networks, interactions or molecules as well as removal of existing ones) and the query network structure.


This project will have both practical and theoretical impact. The developed methods will enable mapping subnetworks of different networks with similar functions. This will improve our understanding of how organisms operate through interactions. The primary impact of this project will be on applications that involve biological networks. It will also impact the studies on other fields such as social networks, distributed computing and homeland security, where a set of operations depend on each other through a complex network. The PI will organize workshops and seminars to disseminate this project throughout the research community. Finally, the code developed as a part of this project will serve as an excellent educational tool to analyze and query biological networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the functions served by different biological entities, such as genes, proteins and metabolites, through interactions in biological networks has been a prime goal in biological studies. One promising way to reach this goal is to perform comparative analysis among biological networks.  Recently, there has been significant work in collecting and constructing biological networks.  As a result, enormous amount of network data is already available. Biological databases today are very large in size and dynamic in nature.  As biological networks became available, several algorithms have been proposed to compare these networks in pairs. These methods have already been successful in demonstrating the benefits of computational analysis of biological networks.  However, so far they have mostly focused on alignment and mining of small and static datasets of networks. As a result, they failed to scale to large networks or large collections of dynamic networks. 

 

This project took a fundamental step to fill this gap and prepare biological studies for the inevitable post genomics era where biological networks are available in massive scale and they evolve over time. More specifically, this project addressed the following problems. (i) We develop scalable and accurate algorithms that allow comparing pairs of biological networks quickly while ensuring mathematically provable confidence bounds on the optimality of the results. (ii) We developed efficient mining methods tailored to find motifs in evolving biological networks. (iii) We developed dynamic indexing methods for searching subnetworks in large collections of biological databases.

 

Our studies in this project have led to 10 journal and 2 peer-reviewed conference papers. This project has supported the training of six Ph.D., one M.S., and two postdoctoral students (not all funded by the project). We have presented the results of this project in various conferences and colloquiums. We have integrated the problems considered in this project with the graduate level bioinformatics course at the University of Florida. We have organized the Computational Network Biology Workshop each year as a part of the ACM International Conference on Bioinformatics and Computational Biology for the last five years.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/08/2018
Modified by: Tamer Kahveci

As biological networks became available, several algorithms have been proposed to compare these networks in pairs. These methods have already been successful in demonstrating the benefits of computational analysis of biological networks. However, so far they have mostly focused on alignment and mining of small and static datasets of networks. As a result, they failed to scale to large networks or large collections of dynamic networks. This project took a fundamental step to fill this gap and prepare biological studies for the inevitable post genomics era where biological networks are available in massive scale and they evolve over time. More specifically, this project addressed the following problems. (i) We develop scalable and accurate algorithms that allow comparing pairs of biological networks quickly while ensuring mathematically provable confidence bounds on the optimality of the results. (ii) We developed efficient mining methods tailored to find motifs in evolving biological networks.
